forumNotes.author: pgsmick
forumNotes.content:
I susccessfully used the USBoot program to place a full, bootable copy of XP-SP3 installation on my USB-HDD.  

It booted successfully to these machines in this order:  
1. Generic PC with ASUS P4P800 mobo--this is the machine it was created on.  
2. Generic PC with Intel DG965RY mobo.  
3. Dell Optiplex 755  
4. HP/Compaq dc5800 slim desktop.  

At each bootup, I declined to allow the Found New Hardware wizard to install any drivers--though I have no idea what other changes got made silently by the OS.  

I then took the drive back to the Intel machine and during bootup got the message that the ...system32\\config\\system file was missing or corrupted. I attempted no repairs.  

I then booted with the same USB-HDD successfully to both the Dell and HP/Compaq.  

I then returned to the Intel, and now the machine acts as if there is no OS at all. It still continues to boot OK to the Dell and Compaq.  

How can I best troubleshoot what has happened here? What is the best way to prevent this from happening again or at least minimize the chances?  

Many thanks,  
Peter.

forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
It's hard to say. ![:poke:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/poke.gif) Can you describe in more details this ![:poke:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/poke.gif): > then returned to the Intel, and now the machine acts as if there is no OS at all.
> How can I best troubleshoot what has happened here? > What is the best way to prevent this from happening again or at least minimize the chances? Use ERUNT to backup the Registry. [http://www.larsheder...nline.de/erunt/](http://www.larshederer.homepage.t-online.de/erunt/ "External link") Backup the Registry right after the usboot.org install. Backup after each succesfull boot, you will have a set of Registry files for each machine. Have another (really portable) way to restore the Registry on each machine, such as a minimal PE or a DOS. Compare Registries to find out what happens/what has changed. (it won't be fast, you'll need to take your time) jaclaz

forumNotes.author: pgsmick
forumNotes.content:
Thanks,  

I'll get the exact text of the message tomorrow, but it is to the effect that there is no system disk, insert disk with correct media. The drive has a multiple-choice boot.ini file on the USBoot drive and I don't get to see that menu on the machine where it won't boot.   

I repeated the test today with a fresh installation of USBoot but in a different order. 1. ASUS--booted OK 2. Intel--booted OK 3. HP/Compaq--booted OK 4. Intel--NO BOOT 5. Dell--booted OK. 6. HP/Compaq--booted OK. 7. ASUS--booted OK.  

I conclude the HP is doing something the Intel mobo doesn't like. So that might make it easier to track down.   

Thanks for the lead on ERUNT, I'll give it a try. Have you ever used a program called RegistryTracker that takes registry snapshots and can analyze the differences between them? I might give that a try also.  

Peter.

forumNotes.author: thasan
pgsmick
forumNotes.content:
thasan:  

I've gotten several USB sticks to boot BartPE on the Intel including a MicroCenter generic 16Gb; a SanCruzer Micro 2.0 Gb, and a Transcend Jet Flash 2.0 Gb.  

Re my USB-HDD, even though the drive fails to boot on the Intel after having gone to the HP, it continues to boot fine to the other machines. I'm puzzled by what's going on since the Intel is refusing to boot the drive way before it gets to reading the registry, so it's getting hard for me to see how any registry changes could be causing this. But I haven't had time to try Jaclaz' advice to record registry changes as the drive boots to each machine.

forumNotes.author: thasan
forumNotes.content:
Well, I think its something else. I found working with number of machines, some of the boot sectors do not work on all. Seems like the hard drive is formatted correctly but your Intel machine has a different expectation than what's on the hard drive.  

In this case, two things have worked for me.   

1) Boot with a VistaPE CD/USB and recreate the hard drive with DISKPART/Clean. Have to remember to rename NTLDR to BOOTMGR after (works 99% of the time)  
2) The Intel machine has a emulation problem; i.e. it expects a USB floppy emulation not USB hard drive emulation. This behaviour I have experienced on various Dell servers. If this is the case, you will have to enter the bios with the USB HD plugged in, and then change the emulation type to HD.  

If all fails, jaclaz's solution is always there.
